docs.title: Travel Documents & Visas
docs.description: Ensure you have the right documents before you travel to Japan. Many nationalities can enter visa-free for up to 90 days.
points: Passport must be valid for the duration of your stay.
Visa exemptions apply to citizens of 68 countries, including the USA, UK, and most of Europe.
Always carry your passport or residence card with you.
Customs declaration is required upon arrival.

culture.title: Culture & Traditions
culture.description: Japanese culture is a fascinating mix of ancient traditions and modern life. Respect for elders, harmony, and politeness are highly valued.
points: Bowing is a customary greeting; the depth of the bow depends on the situation.
Remove your shoes before entering homes, temples, and some restaurants.
Tipping is not customary and may be considered rude.
Speaking quietly in public transportation is expected.

safety.title: Safety & Precautions
safety.description: Japan is one of the safest countries in the world, with very low crime rates. However, it's wise to be prepared for natural disasters like earthquakes.
points: Be aware of earthquake and tsunami procedures.
While rare, be mindful of your belongings in crowded tourist areas.
Typhoon season is from May to October; monitor weather forecasts.
Emergency number is 110 for police and 119 for fire/ambulance.

health.title: Health & Diseases
health.description: Japan has a high standard of healthcare. No specific vaccinations are required for entry, but it's good to be up-to-date on routine shots.
points: Tap water is safe to drink nationwide.
Face masks are commonly worn, especially if you have a cold.
Travel insurance with medical coverage is highly recommended.
Pharmacies (薬, kusuri) are widespread, but some medications may require a prescription.

money.title: Money & Budget
money.description: The currency is the Japanese Yen (JPY). While credit cards are widely accepted in cities, carrying cash is essential, especially in rural areas.
points: Withdraw cash from ATMs at 7-Eleven convenience stores or post offices.
A Japan Rail Pass can save money on extensive train travel.
Budget around ¥10,000-¥15,000 per day for a mid-range trip.
Vending machines are everywhere and offer great value.

connectivity.title: Connectivity & Transport
connectivity.description: Japan's public transport system is world-class. The Shinkansen (bullet train) connects major cities with incredible speed and punctuality.
points: Purchase a Suica or Pasmo card for seamless travel on trains and buses in cities.
Free Wi-Fi is available but can be spotty. Renting a pocket Wi-Fi is a great option.
Google Maps provides excellent, real-time transit information.
Taxis are clean and reliable but can be expensive.

adaptation.title: Adaptation & Mindset
adaptation.description: Embrace the efficiency and order of Japanese society. A little patience and observation will go a long way in helping you blend in.
points: Learn a few basic Japanese phrases like 'Arigato' (Thank you) and 'Sumimasen' (Excuse me).
Be prepared for crowds in major cities like Tokyo and Osaka.
Observe queuing etiquette; always line up in an orderly fashion.
Don't be afraid to ask for help; many people are willing to assist, even with a language barrier.
